page.title: 031945 AND CHEVELEY
page.content: We went to Somerset Court where many of the old people of Cheveley live and talked to some of them about life in 1945. Mr Watkinson told us about the War-mostly the rich had air raid shelters, others sheltered in cupboards. Children still had to go to school when there were air raids and bombs. He said a bomb dropped and set fire to the road by Hill Farm near Cheveley. In those days, there were no flush toilets-you had a hole in the ground with a seat on top. Everyone had to carry gas masks and all the food was rationed. Since then the shops have changed. Now there is only a Post Office, but then there was a butchers, a cycle repairers, a blacksmiths, a bakers, a post office, co-op and cobblers where they would mend your shoes.
